section: Gauri - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Who has established himself as a Siddha, a being of miraculous spiritual powers, by killing his mind? ||1||

melody.description: Gauri creates a mood where the listener is encouraged to strive harder in order to achieve an objective. However, the encouragement given by the Raag does not allow the ego to increase. This therefore creates the atmosphere where the listener is encouraged, but still prevented from becoming arrogant and self-important.

author.author: Saint Kabir
author.description:
Saint Kabir [1440 - 1518] was a Muslim mystic born in Varanasi in India, whose 541 hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. His writings about God are full of love and devotion, very direct and striking in appeal.

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

text: ਕਵਨੁ ਸੁ ਮੁਨਿ ਜੋ ਮਨੁ ਮਾਰੈ ॥
section: Gauri - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Who is that silent sage, who has killed his mind?

transliteration.text: kavan s mun jō man mārai .

melody.description: Gauri creates a mood where the listener is encouraged to strive harder in order to achieve an objective. However, the encouragement given by the Raag does not allow the ego to increase. This therefore creates the atmosphere where the listener is encouraged, but still prevented from becoming arrogant and self-important.

text: ਮਨ ਕਉ ਮਾਰਿ ਕਹਹੁ ਕਿਸੁ ਤਾਰੈ ॥੧॥ ਰਹਾਉ ॥
section: Gauri - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: By killing the mind, tell me, who is saved? ||1||Pause||

transliteration.text: man kau mār kahah kis tārai .1. rahāu .

translation.text: Everyone speaks through the mind.

section: Gauri - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Without killing the mind, devotional worship is not performed. ||2||

section: Gauri - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: She has tightened the noose of emotional attachment and shot the arrow of death. ||1||Pause||

translation.text: By cutting, she cannot be cut, and she cannot be broken.

translation.text: She has become a serpent, and she is eating the world. ||2||

translation.text: Before my very eyes, she has plundered the entire world.

translation.text: Says Kabeer, chanting the Lord's Name, I have escaped her. ||3||30||

author.description:
Saint Kabir [1440 - 1518] was a Muslim mystic born in Varanasi in India, whose 541 hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. His writings about God are full of love and devotion, very direct and striking in appeal.

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

section: Gauri - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Gauree, Kabeer Jee:

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: None
author.description: There is no author associated with this line, as it may be the preamble to the hymn

section: Gauri - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: I have grasped the reins and attached the bridle;

melody.description: Gauri creates a mood where the listener is encouraged to strive harder in order to achieve an objective. However, the encouragement given by the Raag does not allow the ego to increase. This therefore creates the atmosphere where the listener is encouraged, but still prevented from becoming arrogant and self-important.

translation.text: and in the stirrups of intuitive poise, I placed my feet. ||1||Pause||

translation.text: Come, and let me ride you to heaven.

text: ਹਿਚਹਿ ਤ ਪ੍ਰੇਮ ਕੈ ਚਾਬੁਕ ਮਾਰਉ ॥੨॥
section: Gauri - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: If you hold back, then I shall strike you with the whip of spiritual love. ||2||

transliteration.text: hichah t prēm kai chābuk mārau .2.

text: ਕਹਤ ਕਬੀਰ ਭਲੇ ਅਸਵਾਰਾ ॥ ਬੇਦ ਕਤੇਬ ਤੇ ਰਹਹਿ ਨਿਰਾਰਾ ॥੩॥੩੧॥
section: Gauri - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Says Kabeer, those who remain detached from the Vedas, the Koran and the Bible are the best riders. ||3||31||

translation.text: When I chant the Lord's Name, what does it matter if my body burns?

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

section: Gauri - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Says Kabeer, chant the two letters of the Lord's Name - Raa Maa.

melody.description: Gauri creates a mood where the listener is encouraged to strive harder in order to achieve an objective. However, the encouragement given by the Raag does not allow the ego to increase. This therefore creates the atmosphere where the listener is encouraged, but still prevented from becoming arrogant and self-important.

author.author: Saint Kabir
author.description:
Saint Kabir [1440 - 1518] was a Muslim mystic born in Varanasi in India, whose 541 hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. His writings about God are full of love and devotion, very direct and striking in appeal.

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

section: Gauri - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: If He is your Lord and Master, He will protect you. ||3||33||

melody.description: Gauri creates a mood where the listener is encouraged to strive harder in order to achieve an objective. This therefore creates the atmosphere where the listener is encouraged, but still prevented from becoming arrogant and self-important.

His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

section: Gauri - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Gauree, Kabeer Jee, Du-Padas:

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: None
author.description: There is no author associated with this line, as it may be the preamble to the hymn

text: ਨਾ ਮੈ ਜੋਗ ਧਿਆਨ ਚਿਤੁ ਲਾਇਆ ॥
section: Gauri - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: I have not practiced Yoga, or focused my consciousness on meditation.

transliteration.text: nā mai jōg dhiān chit lāiā .

melody.description: Gauri creates a mood where the listener is encouraged to strive harder in order to achieve an objective. section: Gauri - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Without renunciation, I cannot escape Maya. ||1||

section: Gauri - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: How have I passed my life?
